author: KYLE GOON
title: Pac-12 basketball: Larry Scott holds up O'Bannon ruling as NCAA victory
text:
The legal battle over the legitimacy of amateurism in college sports slogs on, but on Thursday, Pac-12 commissioner Larry Scott was raising the NCAA's arm in victory.
Scott told conference media he felt that a Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals decision last month in O'Bannon vs. the NCAA was a win for the NCAA, as the ruling upheld that the ruling body of college sports had no obligation to compensate athletes beyond full cost of attendance stipends.
"In our efforts toward reform, the overriding principle of the Pac-12 is to do the right thing by student athletes, while avoiding treating them as professionals or employees," Scott said. "We agree the court validates the principle that we've been fighting for and stand behind."
  Many legal experts considered the ruling more of a hedged opinion: The three-judge panel did strike down a plan for the NCAA to pay each student athlete up to $5,000 each above cost of attendance, but also found that the NCAA was in violation of federal antitrust laws.
It was certainly lighter on the wallet than District Court Judge Claudia Wilken's initial opinion, which held that the NCAA owed athletes additional compensation.
The lawyers for the plaintiffs — led by former UCLA and Pac-12 player Ed O'Bannon — have filed a request for a larger panel of Ninth Circuit judges to hear the case and perhaps uphold Wilken's initial ruling. Eventually, it could be heard by the Supreme Court.
While Scott is against paying athletes, he was proud to tout several new developments such as full cost of attendance stipends and improved health care coverage. The Pac-12 is also pushing autonomy proposals for athletes to have the rights for commercial opportunities (entirely outside of athletics) and dedicate fewer hours to sports.
"Our student-athletes are getting more support financially, academically, medically, nutritionally than they've ever received before," Scott said. "And I'm proud to say that the Pac-12 is providing tremendous leadership in this area."

Cal's recruiting could reap more victories
After Cuonzo Martin brought in two of the top-10 prospects in the country in one class, a lot of people would love to know his secret.
The second-year Cal coach says his secret isn't very secret at all: It's his school's reputation as the No. 1 public university in the world and the No. 3 global university.
"Those are the stats that as a father that I'm consumed with," he said. "The wins will come and go, but when you get those types of numbers, you want to be here. And that's how I sell my program."
That may be the case, but newcomers Ivan Rabb and Jaylen Brown may not hang around long enough to earn degrees. Both were consensus five-star prospects in the 2015 class, and both are candidates to be one-and-done players.
In the meantime, they dramatically boost Cal's chances of competing for a conference title. Brown is a 6-foot-7 small forward in the mold of former Arizona standout Stanley Johnson who can drive and score with power. Rabb is a physical forward who gives Cal automatic credibility in the post.
Even current players tend to pump their fists when landing recruits of that caliber, Tyrone Wallace said.
"Yeah, we celebrate," said Wallace, who himself is a returning all-conference player. "I think the players do play a large role in getting those players to come, because we're going to be the people that they're going to play with at the end of the day. So I think if we can get a good feel for each other and get along well, it all works in the end."
